MILITARY HISTORY of Major Walter Reed, Surgeon, U. S. Army, as
far as shown by the records of the Surgeon General's Office.

Major Reed was appointed Assistant Surgeon, U. S. Army, with
rank of 1st Lieutenant June 26, 1875; promoted Assistant Surgeon
with the rank of Captain June 26, 1880; and Surgeon with the rank
of Major December 4, 1893, and at the time of his death was first
on the list of Majors in the Medical Department:
His record of service is as follows:
Camp Apache, August 10, 1876 to May 10, 1880;

Awaiting orders and on leave of absence from May 10, 1880 to August
31, 1880;
At Headquarters awaiting orders, September 19 to 23, 1880;

En route to and at Fort Ontario, N. Y., September 23, 1880 to Febru-
ary 23, 1881;
At Fort McHenry, Maryland, and awaiting orders Feb. 24 to May 2, 1881;
At Washington Barracks, D. C. May 2, 1881 to November 17, 1882;

In the Department of the Platte, November 17, 1882 to July 31, 1887,
during which period was on duty at Headquarters awaiting orders
November 17, to December 4, 1882; On duty as Attending Surgeon Head-
quarters Department of the Platte, Omaha, Nebraska, December 4, 1882
to January 1, 1883;
At Fort Omaha, Nebraska, January 2 to October 4, 1883;
At Fort Sidney, Nebraska, October 5, 1883 to August 4, 1884;
At Fort Robinson, Nebraska, August 8, 1884 to July 31, 1887;

At Baltimore, Maryland, as Attending Surgeon and Examiner of Recruits
October 6, 1890 to October 31, 1891;

In the office of the Surgeon General of the Army as Curator, Army
3.
Medical Museum, from September 6, 1893 to November 23, 1902 and as
Librarian in charge Library, Surgeon General's Office from November
1, 1902 to November 23, 1902;

Was appointed a member of the Faculty of the Army Medical School in
September 1893;

Member of the Army Medical Board at Washington, D. C., September 11,
1893 to October 21, 1893 and October 1 to October 31, 1895, Septem-
ber 23 to October 27, 1896, and September 27 to November 6, 1897,
Member of Cholera hand Board May 2 to July 12, 1898;

On detached duty making inspections of Camps and Field Hospitals,
August 1 to 8, 1898;

Member Typhoid Fever Board and to inspect certain Camps, August 20
to September 18, 1898;

Member of board to investigate causes of Typhoid Fever, September
25 to October 10, 1898;
Inspecting buildings at Natural Bridge, Va., October 18 to 25, 1898;

En route to and returning from inspection duty at Puerto Principe,
Cuba, April 19 to May 9, 1899;
Detached duty at Fort Thomas, Ky., September 28 to 30, 1899;

Delegate to American Public Health Association at Minneapolis, Minn.,
October 31 to November 3, 1899;

Member of Board of Medical Officers at Camp Columbia, Cuba,
for the purpose of pursuing scientific investigation with reference
to infectious diseases prevalent in Island of Cuba, June 26 to July
31, 1900.

En route to and on duty in Cuba investigating causes of Yellow Fever
September 27 to October 13, 1900;

Delegate to American Public Health Association Indianapolis, Indiana,
October 21 to 27, 1900.

On detached duty in Cuba investigating infectious diseases prevalent
in the Island of Cuba, November 1, 1900 to February 12, 1901; during
which period representied Medical Dept., of the Army at Pan American
Medical Congress, Havana, Cuba, in February 1901;

Delegate to American Public Health Association, Buffalo, K. Y.,
September 16 to 20, 1901;

Died at U. S. Army General Hospital, Washington Barracks, D. C., at
2 A. M. November 23, 1903 from appendicitis for which an operation
was performed Monday the 17th instant.

Major Reed was born in Gloucester County, Va., September 13, 1851
Graduated from the Medical Department, University of Virginia in
1869 and Bellevue Hospital Medical College New York City, N. Y., 1872.
Of Major Reed's work in the Medical Department and his scientific
researches, it is probable a complete history can never be obtained.
His eminence as a bacteriologist, and in practical hygiene as applied
to military life (student of all forms of bacteria) led to his being
5.
intrusted with special investigations, which were interrupted by his
death, and which, it is now believed, will never be completed. He
was regarded by his associates as a man who combined an unusual de-
gree of scientific accuracy with calm judgment which rendered him
invaluable in searching out the causes of epidemic diseases and trac-
ing their progress.

In 1901 he began the investigation of the cause and the prev-
alence of yellow fever, conducting his investigations at Quemados,
near Havana, where he established headquarters and was given every
facility for conducting his experiments.

The conditions in Cuba in 1901 were such as made the investiga-
tions of Major Reed and his corps of assistants of special moment.
An epidemic of yellow fever existed despite the efforts of the sani-
tary experts, led by General Wood, who were endeavoring to stamp
out the disease. The houses of persons infected were subjected to
rigid disinfection. Furniture was destroyed and every possible pre-
caution was taken to prevent the spread of the disease under the old
treatment. Major Reed became convinced that proper sanitation was
not all that was needed. He believed that some other agency than
accumulations of filth was responsible for the spread of the dis-
ease, and his attention was attracted to the fact that it took much
longer for a house to become infected, than the usual time of incuba-
tion. This suggested a biting insect as an intermediate host of the
parasite, and he asked and promptly received from General Wood per-
6.
mission to make experiments with mosquitoes, as the conveyers of
yellow fever, and a liberal supply of money for these experiments. It
was thus determined beyond question that through a certain species
of mosquito the yellow fever germ was disseminated.

The degree of bachelor of arts was conferred on Major Reed by
the Harvard University in June 1902, because, as President Eliot
stated when the degree as awarded, Major Reed had demonstrated how
to rid the world of yellow fever. About the same time the degree
of master of arts was conferred upon Major Reed by the University of
Michigan at Ann Arbor, Michigan.
